text: my name is Kyle Patrick Alvarez and I'm
the director of the Stanford Prison
Experiment this thing takes place a
little bit before the halfway point of
the film when two shifts of the guards
decide to band together in order to try
to suppress the prisoner rebellion
that's been getting stronger and
stronger throughout the first half of
the film one of the tricky aspects of
this scene was that we wanted to create
a sense that a lot of violence was
happening without actually showing
anything no one was actually ever really
severely hurt bruised there's no blood
and so for the first time and the three
films I've made we decided to shoot in
slow motion to create this sort of
otherworldly feeling that what's
happening is actually worse than it
really was which is a lot of what
happened during this experiment it was
really in their heads and so we had to
create the special lighting rigs in
order to shoot this slow of an image you
know you can't light that traditionally
in order for it to get this really
really impressionistic feeling and this
next shot that comes up in a moment
you'll see it's an overhead shot is
easily the most complex shot in the film
we wanted to kind of create a really
strong spatial relationship of what was
happening in this hallway but also give
the impression that we the audience were
looking down at this experiment like as
if they were rats in a maze and it you
know to be able to build a rig and on a
small film like this and put a camera
and get a get a sort of ambitious shot
like that was something we planned
really far ahead of time you know we had
to build special rigs for the lighting
we had to bring in a special camera for
it but I'm really proud about how the
shot came out here you see all the
researchers watching the experiment on
the monitor and we actually shot this
you know nearly a month later from the
previous stuff and so we would pump the
footage we shot on a monitor to give
Billy Crudup who's playing doctor Phil
Zimbardo something to react to and in
this scene you see Johnny Simmons as one
of the prisoners and Kier Gilchrist is
one of the guards face off and until now
Johnny's been a very passive guy sort of
saying we shouldn't you know we should
just follow our rules we should just do
and obey and do what they're saying and
this is sort of the first time he stands
up and this is the only scene in the
film where we shot over the shoulders on
a steady camera
and it could still kept that active
movement from the sweeping shots of the
previous sequence and I'd never done it
before but the study came out right here
is such a good job of sort of being a
part of the scene and moving in with
Johnny as he's sort of changing in the
moment no sorry
all
